awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract
GOALI: Extreme Environment Microcontrollers
Project Objectives:

The market needs of extreme environment electronics encompass many commercial applications such as integrated gate drivers in power industry, in-engine sensing and control in automobile industry, well condition monitoring and drilling assistance in oil/gas exploration, cryogenic high-field magnet creation in medical imaging instrumentation, and many others like superconducting computing and energy storage systems, laser industry, space exploration, in-field distributed sensors, magnetic levitation transport systems, and infrared systems.

Non-Technical Abstract:
The extreme environments pose significant challenges to electronics, especially for digital integrated circuits: for extreme temperature environments, since the circuit speed is a strong function of temperature, timing control becomes very difficult across wide temperature ranges; for unstable energy source environment, the unstable or low power supply causes large variations in circuit speed as well. In the prevailing clocked synchronous digital integrated circuits, synchronized clocks are used to control and coordinate the circuit operation, along with a set of timing constraints such as setup and hold times. These critical timing constraints can be easily broken in extreme environments due to the circuit speed changes, thereby inducing system malfunction. Therefore, innovations are needed to solve these problems and develop extreme environment electronics in order to make contributions to the commercial industry discussed above in efficient and reliable sensing, communication, control, and data processing subsystems.
Technical Abstract

This GOALI project is a collaborative effort between the University of Arkansas and Radiance Technologies to develop quasi-delay insensitive asynchronous microcontrollers capable of operating reliably under extreme environments without extra protection or control/adjustment. Quasi-delay insensitive asynchronous logic like the NULL Convention Logic (NCL) uses local handshaking protocols in lieu of global clocks to control the circuit behavior. Individual gate delay has no impact on the correctness of the circuit's outputs. This feature guarantees robust circuit operation under extreme environments, making NCL a promising candidate for designing microcontrollers for such applications. However, innovations in microcontroller architecture and NCL circuit design are needed to improve performance, reduce overhead, and enhance the robustness: at the architecture-level, the prevailing bus architecture is unsuitable for NCL and needs to be replaced; the distributed storage mechanism is the weakest link of circuit operation and needs to be reorganized; and the external interrupt handling needs to redesigned as fully asynchronous. At the circuit-level, transistors need to be resized to improve the reliability under extreme environments; NCL logic gate design needs to be modified for low supply voltages; and NCL logic transformation needs to be investigated to improve the performance. With the industry-standard guidance, experience, and assistance from Radiance Technologies, a prototype NCL microcontroller incorporating the above innovations will be designed, fabricated, and tested. The results will be analyzed for further improvements, dissemination, and technology transfer for potential commercialization.

por.por_cntn:
The term “extreme environment” usually refers to any environment that is outside the limits defined by commercial or military applications. The market needs of extreme environment electronics encompass many applications: in power industry, integrated power modules like gate drivers require the associated digital, analog, and power electronics operating under temperatures as high as 300 ºC; in automobile industry, the most direct method of improving the efficiency and reducing the emissions of any internal combustion engine (ICE) is through electronic control, which requires sensors and controllers to be placed inside the ICE in order to provide real-time, in situ feedback control to each cylinder, in which a wide temperature range between -55 ºC to 350 ºC is introduced; oil/gas exploration needs electronics to both monitor the condition of the well and provide assistance with the drilling, which operate at temperatures beyond 300 ºC; medical imaging instrumentation like MRI uses liquid helium (4 Kelvin or -269 ºC) to create the cryogenic high-field magnet, which is controlled and surrounded by various electronic components; laser industry incorporates optical oscillators operating at temperatures around 124 K (-149 ºC) to generate ultra-stable laser cavities. The optical signals are then translated into electrical signals and processed by digital and analog electronics; superconducting computing and energy storage systems operate under temperatures between 4 K (-269 ºC) and 92 K (-181 ºC) for ultra-fast speed, ultra-low power, and maximized energy density; space exploration demands electronics capable of sustaining +150 ºC when facing the sun and -230 ºC when not facing the sun; while near- and sub-threshold operation of CMOS integrated circuits (ICs) have been well-studied for maximizing energy efficiency, most of these ICs operate under stable, comfortable, and reliable environments. On the other hand, applications like in-field distributed sensors not only rely on harvested energy to support the operation, but also experience unstable energy source and wide swings in ambient temperature.

Extreme environments pose significant challenges to electronics, especially for digital ICs. For extreme environments, wide swings of temperature and fluctuations of supply voltage cause drastic changes in MOS device switching speed, which induce large variations in gate delays. The prevailing digital ICs are synchronous, i.e., they use synchronized clocks to control the circuit operation. The total delay of any pipeline stage must be shorter than the clock period, plus the setup time and hold time constraints. These critical timing requirements can be easily broken in extreme environments due to the delay changes in every logic gate, thereby inducing system malfunction.

This GOALI project, which is a collaborative effort between the University of Arkansas and Radiance Technologies, focuses on extreme environments that present ultra-high temperature, cryogenic temperature, wide temperature swings, and unstable energy source (supply voltage). This project proposes to solve the abovementioned problem and develop microcontrollers capable of operating reliably under extreme environments without extra protection or control/adjustment using quasi-delay insensitive (QDI) asynchronous logic. QDI logic like the NULL Convention Logic (NCL) uses local handshaking protocols in lieu of global clocks to control the circuit behavior. Individual gate delay has no impact on the correctness of the circuit’s outputs. As long as the transistors can switch properly (regardless of the speed), NCL circuits will be able to function correctly, i.e., correct-by-construction. This flexible timing requirement feature guarantees robust circuit operation under extreme environments, making QDI logic like NCL a promising candidate for designing digital ICs, such as microcontrollers, for the abovementioned applications. During the project, the team has completed all proposed research tasks: #1 design and evaluation of bus alternatives; #2 reorganization of storage components; #3 complete desynchronization of interrupt handling mechanism; #4 transistor sizing under extreme temperatures; #5 NCL threshold gate design modification; #6 transformation of NCL circuits; #7 prototype NCL microcontroller design and integration; and #8 prototype fabrication and testing. Technical outcomes have been broadly disseminated through publications and student dissertations/theses.

The team has been working closely with the industry partner, Radiance Technologies, throughout the project period, who provided technical guidance on directing the developed asynchronous microcontroller to satisfy the practical needs from the industry’s perspective, and initiating the effort to incorporate the underlying technology into their specific applications. Moreover, they hired multiple students from the team as interns to facilitate circuit design communication and provide students with invaluable industry experience. The GOALI partner will continue to work with the team to apply for other federal funding opportunities to further develop the technology and incorporate it into more government and industrial applications.

Educational goals including curriculum development, undergraduate and graduate research activities, women and minority student recruiting, and K-12 student mentoring have been achieved. Course modules have been developed in the PI’s classes and the research findings from this project have been incorporated. A number of undergraduate and graduate students, multiple of whom are from underrepresented groups, were recruited and worked on various research tasks.
